title: Are you responsible for what other people of your race do? - Quora

response.answer_text: No you are not, but racists will hold you responsible anyway, because you don’t exist as an individual to them. And the reality is some groups of people on earth are far more group oriented than others, and are more likely to judge you by whatever group they perceive you to belong to, especially if they don’t know you as an individual. Most of the world is not embracing “Western Individuality”, that’s what WEIRD (western educated industrialized rich and democratic) people do. My advice, stop worrying about people and things you cannot change. You really can’t control the actions of others, all you can control in the end is yourself. I would say if it bothers you so much, then do something to improve the average situation of your group. You might be able to influence some folks (who influence some other folks) to act the way you want. Change starts with a person who has a dream that makes plans to try to change things. Usually an unreasonable person that does not accept the way the world is but wants to make the world fit their vision. Most people aren’t successful in this, but sometimes…it does happen.

One is not responsible for the behavior of others; however, according to most ethical perspectives, they are responsible for the welfare of others; which includes some responsibility to those who may be harmed by the behavior of others, and that responsibility may extend to proactive intervention. “To sin by silence when they should protest makes cowards of men.” Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) “To see what is right and not to do it is cowardice.” Confucius, c. 551-479 B.C.E. “A coward is incapable of exhibiting love; it is the prerogative of the brave.” Mohandas (Mahatma) Gandhi (1869-1948) “The best index to a person's character is how he treats people who can't do him any good, and how he treats people who can't fight back.” Abigail Van Buren “The person who has nothing for which he is willing to fight, nothing which is more important than his own personal safety, is a miserable creature and has no chance of being free unless made and kept so by the exertions of better men than himself.” John Stuart Mill (1806-1873) “The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.” Edmund Burke, 1729-1797 “We should aim for our children to be good people, and to live ethical lives that manifest concern for others as well as for themselves. … That's a central part of philosophy, of ethics. What do I owe to strangers? What do I owe to my family? What is it to live a good life? Those are questions which we face as individuals.” Peter A. D. Singer, Australian moral philosopher, Ira W. DeCamp Professor of Bioethics at Princeton University, and Laureate Professor at the Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics at the University of Melbourne.

I am barely responsible for what I do, and I’m generally quite together as a person. I can feel annoyed that someone that I relate to in some way (race, gender, ability etc) misuses their status, and I challenge this where I can, but I don't take the burdens of whitekind onto my shoulders. I would need a pretty big and misplaced ego to shoulder that kind of responsibility.

No, I am not but we live in a world where if one person of a certain race does something, the perception of all of those people are now thrown into that same category. Just like a person who says they are a Christian but do not exhibit Christian values cannot in essence truly be a Christian, let alone be held an example for all people who state they are Christians.

Of course not. You cannot control others’ actions, only your own. That said, the actions you can take include influencing your peers, or setting expectations of your own and others’ actions. You are an active participant in your own culture, whatever that is, and you can choose to shape it.

Yes. My contrarian opinion is that you are. Not legally responsible or liable. But If you are proud of the positive things other people of your race, language, or ethnicity do. If you think that defines you. then you should jolly well take ownership of the negative things too. That’s the unpopular flip side of identity politics.
No it does not matter what men of my race do they have a value I do not have as they are men liked by other men and women. I have no use for women or men even when the products are aimed at me.
As much as I am for my own species …..
